title: Corruption Currents: Judge Questions Mueller’s Motivations - Risk & Compliance Journal. - WSJ
text:
0 COMMENTS Special Counsel Robert Mueller departs after a meeting on Capitol Hill in Washington last year. Photo: Associated Press
A daily roundup of corruption news from across the Web. We also provide a daily roundup of important risk & compliance stories vi a our daily newsletter, The Morning Risk Report, which readers can sign up for here . Follow us on Twitter at @WSJRisk.
Bribery:
A new subpoena was issued in the ongoing investigation of corruption in Atlanta’s city government. (AJC)
A foreman in charge of elevators at the University of Illinois at Chicago was arrested on federal bribery charges; he pleaded not guilty. Also arrested was the owner of the elevator company accused of paying the foreman to win business. The articles didn’t include a response from the owner, or her lawyer. (CST, CT)
The chief of staff to the president of Sri Lanka was arrested on bribery charges. The article had no response from the official. (SLBC)
Money Laundering:
Regulators in Denmark slammed Danske Bank for “ serious shortcomings ” in its anti-money laundering program related to the bank’s dealings in Estonia. The bank’s chief executive apologized . (WP, Bloomberg)
An Italian businessman will be extradited to his home country from Slovakia to face drug and money-laundering charges. The businessman wasn’t Quote: : d. (Reuters)
Seven people in Indiana are charged with laundering money through teppanyaki restaurants; none of the suspects were Quote: : d. (WRTV)
A number of Caribbean nations are calling unfair a law approved by U.K. legislators to require British Overseas Territories in the Caribbean and elsewhere to establish public registers of beneficial company ownership. (Telesur)
Cybercrime/Privacy:
Lawmakers in Bermuda are working on legislation to facilitate and oversee investment in blockchain and cryptocurrencies . (Bloomberg)
Sanctions:
The U.S. will face some challenges if it tries to reinstate sanctions against Iran. Has U.S. President Donald Trump already decided to end the nuclear deal? (FA, AS)
China is asking the U.S. to reconsider its decision to ban Chinese telecommunications equipment maker ZTE from buying components and software from U.S. businesses. (Reuters)
A human-rights advocate says Chinese media outlets that broadcast forced confessions orchestrated by the government should be subject to sanctions under the Magnitsky Act. (CNN)
Whistleblowers:
Complaints from whistleblower mechanics at Southwest Airlines say the airline pressures staff not to report possible safety concerns. The company disputed the claim. (NBCDallas)
General Anticorruption:
A federal judge in Virginia on Friday questioned the motivation of Special Prosecutor Robert Mueller in bringing tax and bank-fraud charges against former Trump campaign manager Paul Manafort. Mr. Manafort wants the charges against him dismissed. (WP, WP)
Did the admission by Trump attorney Rudolph Giuliani that the president knew about a payment to porn star Stormy Daniels open the president to new legal jeopardy ? Some observers say the move may have backfired . (NYT, WP)
A U.S. senator representing Mississippi said he was among the victims of an investment fraud. (AP)
Many of the officials accused of corruption by Philippines President Rodrigo Duterte have yet to be charged , while two are back in the government. A spokesman for the president said it isn’t Mr. Duterte’s job to file charges. (Rappler)
Some European Union countries are pulling back on their efforts to fight corruption, a report claims. The report from the Council of Europe’s Group of States Against Corruption said several countries have reversed reforms and are in danger of falling out of compliance with international standards. (Politico, NE)
A former hedge fund manager was sentenced to six years in prison for stealing from investors. (Reuters)
A former official at the University of Texas law school was arrested as part of a fraud investigation. The school says it is cooperating with authorities. Neither the official nor his attorney could be reached. (TT)
Scammers and criminals are stealing $37 billion a year from elderly people in the U.S. (Bloomberg)
